712479f-a.text:
33 East 38th Street, north side, between Park and Madison Avenues.
1911.
ift of E. M. Knox.

722078f-a.text:
(1)
Park Ave., west side, north from and including 38th Street, to and including 42nd Street. The Grand Central Railroad Terminal
is seen in the background.
December 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.
(2)
The same, showing a closer view, north from and including 40th Street.
December 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

(1)
Park Ave., west side, north from and including 38th Street, to and including 42nd Street. The Grand Central Railroad Terminal

722074f-a.text:
Park Avenue, north from 38th Street, showing the nearly comgleted New York Centra. Builcing towering over Grand Central Terminal. The following buildings in the picture are later to be denolished: the house shown on the S. W. corner of 39th Street (1933), the S. W. corner of 40th Street and the two houses adjoining it on the south (1931), the four houses from the N. E. corner of 39th Street north (1933), and the Hotel Belnont in the block above the old Murray Hill. The Princeton Club is the building on the N. W. corner of 39th Street. Above the house on the N. W. corner of 39th Street one can see a little bit of the building at 60 East 42nd Street which is about to give
place to the new Lincoln Building.
1928.
Cosmo Photo Co.
MAY BE REPRODUCRD with creait.

712477f-a.text:
38th Street, west from and including Park Avenue, showing the new
70 Park Avenue Hotel on the N.W. corner.
June 14, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722082f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 38th Streets, seen from the roof of 271 Madison Avenue, and showing the East River in the
background.
77 Park Avenue, on the S.E. corner of 39th Street, was erected in 1924, and 67 Park Avenue, on the N.E. corner of 38th Street, was completed in 1922 on the site of the old Charles D. Barney residence. The building in the middle of the block was erected between these two in point of time. East of Park Avenue is shown the colored tower of Town House Apartments, 108 East 38th
Street, erected in 1930.
The single smoke-stack seen in the background is part of the New York Steam Corporation's plant on the east side of First Avenue
between 35th and 36th Streets.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722076f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, west side, from 38th to 39th Streets, including the
N.W. corner of 39th Street.
The buildings on the S.W. corner of 39th Street are being demolished. The house on the N.W. corner has been occupied by the Princeton Club since 1923. In the background, from left to right, three skyscrapers tower, The New York Trust Company's building at 277 Madison Avenue, the Lefcourt Colonial Building at 297 Madison Avenue (S.E. corner of 4lst Street), and the Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street, the first built in
1931 and the other two late in 1929.
September 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, not showing the 38th Street corner, a month later.
Demolition is now complete.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Park Avenue, west side, from 38th to 39th Streets, including the
N.W. corner of 39th Street.
The buildings on the S.W. corner of 39th Street are being demolished. The house on the N.W. corner has been occupied by the Princeton Club since 1923. In the background, from left to right, three skyscrapers tower, The New York Trust Company's building at 277 Madison Avenue, the Lefcourt Colonial Building at 297 Madison Avenue (S.E. corner of 4lst Street), and the Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street, the first built in
1931 and the other two late in 1929.
September 9, 1933.

(2)

Demolition is now complete.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

722083f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 38th Streets, looking across
the S.W. corner of 39th Street.
These three apartment houses were built during the years 1922-24, No. 67 on the N.E. corner of 38th Street, on the site of the old Charles D. Barney residence, being the first. Behind it hrises the colored tower of own House Apartments at 108 East
38th Street, built in 1930.
In the foreground the old houses on the S.W. corner of 39th
Street are being demolished.
September 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, demolition on the S.W. corner of 39th Street now
being practically complete.
September 3O, 1933.
P. L. Sperr, Photographem.

Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 38th Streets, looking across

722100f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from 40th to 38th Streets, showing the new building recently erected on the S.W. corner of 40th St eet, and the clearing at the S.W. corner of 39th Street. The Princeton
Club is on the H .W. corner of 39th Street.
The Empire State Building, at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, towers
in the background.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722101f.text:
Park Ave., east side, south from East 40th (left) to 38th Streets, and showing in the foreground W.P.A. employees rebuilding the former railroad and street car tunnel. Vehicular traffio will ase this in
the future.
May 6, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

722071f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, north from East 38th Street.  At 39th Street is a vacant lot at the S.W. corner and the Princeton Club opposite.  Beyond the latter is a 2-story taxpayer at 40th Street and the old Murray Hill Hotel.  Grand Central Station is at the right margin.  Towering overhead are several of the huge office buildings that form a part of the 42nd Street--Grand Central sky-line.  The three shown are Johns Vanaville, Lefoourt-Colonial and the Lincoln Buildings.
On the left is a portion of the apartment-hotel identified as No. 70 Park Avenue.  This is at the N.W. corner of 38th Street.
May 27, 1939
Views 1,2
P.L. Sperr
VIEW 1, A2 NEG. # 4280

722071f-b.text:
Park Avenue, west side, north from East 38th Street.  At 39th Street is a vacant lot at the S.W. corner and the Princeton Club opposite.  Beyond the latter is a 2-story taxpayer at 40th Street and the old Murray Hill Hotel.  Grand Central Station is at the right margin.  Towering overhead are several of the huge office buildings that form a part of the 42nd Street--Grand Central sky-line.  The three shown are Johns Vanaville, Lefoourt-Colonial and the Lincoln Buildings.
On the left is a portion of the apartment-hotel identified as No. 70 Park Avenue.  This is at the N.W. corner of 38th Street.
May 27, 1939
Views 1,2
P.L. Sperr
VIEW 1, A2 NEG. # 4280
